About

I've dedicated my life and career to solving problems, starting from humble beginnings like picking stones and baling hay in farm fields to mastering the art of transforming rotary engine cars in garages. At the age of 22, I ventured into entrepreneurship, building a multi-million dollar advertising agency over a decade. After successfully selling the business to a New York holding company, my trajectory shifted as I joined the M&A team, contributing to the acquisition of 19 companies within three years.

While continuing to build and advise various ventures, I recognized that there are monumental global challenges demanding attention, such as Climate Change, World Hunger, and the imperative for a healthier planet. Motivated by a desire to make a substantial impact, I took part in commercializing and scaling a groundbreaking biotechnology company.

This journey unveiled a crucial realization—the necessity for a circular project development company capable of rapidly constructing large-scale, impactful technology projects worldwide. Fueled by a sense of urgency, given the staggering number of people facing starvation daily and the alarming pace of climate change, I founded Orbital Farm in 2018.

Today, Orbital Farm is actively engaged in building closed-loop systems with the potential to produce vaccines, medicines, hydrogen energy, and food on a global scale, using water, CO2, and electricity as primary resources. Our vision extends to establishing 200 circular mega projects across the planet, aiming to support and nourish billions of people on Earth while dedicating the next two decades to prototyping and developing technology for future space exploration.

For me, Orbital Farm isn't just a business; it's my life's work, my dream, and my purpose—a commitment to creating a sustainable and transformative future.
… more

Featured

Post

Grateful for another year & energized by the impact ahead!

As I mark my birthday today, I'm taking a moment to reflect on a year of incredible growth, learning, and, most importantly, impact. It's been a privilege to see visions turn into tangible progress, particularly in areas I'm deeply passionate about.

This past year has been rich with opportunities to drive change:
- My speaking engagements, including at the World Summit AI last month, have been invaluable for sharing insights and fostering dialogue on critical industry advancements as we transition to a new AI world driving energy, water and systems changes globally.
- Collaborating with the forward-thinking team at ESSA Technologies Ltd continues to be a rewarding experience and learning from brilliant scientists who deeply understand and value our natural world. 
- My involvement in Climate Week NYC, through talks and leading sessions, reinforced the urgency and opportunity in sustainable industrial development and finance to step up.
- Spearheading initiatives in Sustainable AI datacenters has been a key focus, exploring how technology can scale responsibly – a core tenet of the work we are driving at Impactful Capital.
- Our progress with Green Bonds, in partnership with the Climate Bonds Initiative, and the positive traction we're seeing, underscore the power of innovative finance in achieving climate goals. This strategic approach is central to how I view long-term value creation and change at global scales.
- It's been immensely fulfilling to connect with hundreds of brilliant founders and groundbreaking technologies, and world changing projects helping them navigate the path to funding and growth. This exposure to cutting-edge innovation constantly refines my perspective. It gives me unbelievable hope and reaffirms my understanding of how solvable the challenges we are facing are today.
- Exploring the frontiers of space technology with NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration and NIAC remains one of my favorite activities and has also been a fascinating reminder of the boundless potential of human ingenuity.

These experiences affirm my belief that strategic, informed capital can be a powerful force for good. My mission is to identify and support these transformative opportunities, and I'm incredibly proud of the strides we're making in the work, the projects and the world.

Thank you to my Wife and Daughter, my team members, network of colleagues, mentors, and friends who have been part of this journey. I truly value the connections with fellow leaders, investors, and innovators who share a commitment to building a more sustainable and prosperous future.

I’m more energized than ever for what’s next and always welcome conversations with those who are passionate about shaping a truly impactful tomorrow.
#BirthdayReflection #ImpactInvesting #SustainableFinance #Innovation #ThoughtLeadership #FamilyOffices #LimitedPartners #OrbitalFarm #ImpactfulCapital

Rachel Hemingway • 2nd

Climate Bonds Initiative - Head of Strategic Programme Design

2w • Edited • 

Calling all adaptation and resilience experts - we're hiring a global resilience lead to drive forward and provide expert leadership for our new resilience programme. This programme is intended to provide the tools and policy frameworks needed to ensure all investments can be future-proofed against projected climate impacts whilst avoiding harm to other objectives such as mitigation, biodiversity protection and environmental justice. 

This is not a position that will involve structuring financial instruments or managing funds - Climate Bonds is an NGO that develops tools to define climate credibility. We are looking for strategic thinkers with practitioner experience of adaptation and resilience who are able to drive internal and external alignment and support for our mission. 
  
Interviews will be held on a rolling basis and we are looking to fill the position quickly. 

Flexible, home-based working - globally remote but with a preference for +/- 4 hours from GMT.  

We will be hiring a number of resilience experts to fill upcoming senior to junior roles so watch this space  

Click on the link below to apply.

I’m looking for a great new team member! 

The passion that motivates our work everyday is that “an innovative economy needs an innovative government.” To this end, we work to identify and advance important legislative and policy options that will accelerate the creation of globally competitive opportunities, jobs and prosperity in Canada, and create a more inclusive, resilient, and sustainable future.

Specifically, we’re hiring a new Parliamentary Research Assistant to help us to identify important initiatives that will drive competition, innovation, the discovery and application of important technologies, and modernize procurement and regulation.

This position offers the opportunity to support our office’s work through research, analysis and strategic communication. You will contribute directly to:

👉 Shaping legislation and policy, 
👉 Engaging with stakeholders and other legislators,
👉 Deciding how we engage on a given issue, and
👉 Supporting the smooth functioning of a very busy office.

Our hope is that this role will help you to launch a highly engaging, exciting and rewarding career at the Senate and beyond.

2w • 

Article 6.4 is the mechanism that will unlock significant potential for low cost carbon sequestration to happen at scale. When we can unburden the geographical limitations of countries abilities to sequester carbon the lower cost, permanent sequestration places will become highly valuable, and more critically, abundantly used.

Beatriz Granziera • 2nd

Senior Climate Policy Advisor at The Nature Conservancy

2w • Edited • 

💥 We have a decision! 🌍 The #Article6.4 Supervisory Body has just adopted the rules on #permanence, after an intense week of negotiations

Here’s a quick summary of where things landed.

💡 Main takeaway 💡 : This is a much better text than what we had at the start of the week. It was #encouraging to see several countries raising their voices to keep nature in the process and to ensure that the overwhelming reaction from so many stakeholders was taken into account. There is still work to be done and challenges ahead for the participation of Nature in this mechanism, but these will be dealt with within the specific context of each activity.

Here are the four main “buckets” of the decision:

🌏 Post-crediting monitoring
The idea of #“indefinite” post-crediting monitoring has been #rejected by the SBM. Instead, in the future, each #methodology (not the “standard”) will determine how many years of monitoring are required — reflecting that different sectors have different monitoring needs. The Supervisory Body will still have to approve it, as it would have been the case anyway. A notable new clarification is the separation of responsibilities and liabilities after the crediting period: one for monitoring, and another for addressing reversals. This could allow a host country or third party to assume monitoring responsibilities, while the liability for remediating reversals remains with the activity participants until they can provide alternative measures to remediate reversals, such as insurance, guarantees or financial products.

🌏 Negligible risk of reversals
Fixed numerical rates for “negligible risk” were removed. Instead, the percentage defining a negligible risk will be established within each methodology and reflected in the risk assessment tool — This ensures that you define how to assess risk, BEFORE defining risk rates, which is crucial. This will be presented as a #“package” which was the original mandate and requested by many stakeholders.

🌏 Remediation actions to address reversals
This section now clarifies possible “exit” options for projects if they fully remediate the risk of reversals: Cancelling an equivalent number of credits, or transferring risk through insurance or third-party guarantees. The Supervisory Body will provide further guidance, but it’s essential that flexibility and #innovation remain central — including options like buffer pools, insurance products, and transfer of liability to third parties.

🌏 ”Help, host countries!”
A more technical but important point: when (or whether) a corresponding adjustment should be applied to units held in the buffer pool. There’s a general consensus that neither the SBM nor the MEP has the authority to decide on the point of the first transfer (which triggers the corresponding adjustment). The SBM will consider the accounting implications and the application of corresponding adjustments, opening a call for inputs from host countries to gather practical guidance.

Scot Bryson

3w • 

The latest EAT Lancet report of out! A moment to take stock and understand the wider systems of our food and the growing sector of emissions and the most exposed to a volatile world. We are very unprepared for the coming decades and we are not even walking at the pace needed. We should be sprinting towards a transition!

With the clear goals to make adjustments towards, I'm most excited about the increase in vegetable and legumes production! The water savings and reducing the nitrogen & phosphorus I think we'll do a great job at with the deployment of already existing better technology, monitoring and capture. 

I do have a deep concern with achieving our red meat & GHG emissions reductions though. This is going to be very difficult.

Looking forward to hearing others perspective on this and where you see some of the near term opportunities for big wins? Who are the large firms that are the willing to make big changes in 2026? 

Please tag specificly who I should connect with to help finance their transition or supply chains to enable the changes we need to achieve?

#investment #greenbonds #climate #climatebonds #agriculture #food
… more

Reyes Tirado • 2nd

Global Lead for Agrifood | Climate Finance & Sustainable Agriculture Expertise | Strategic Leadership in Managing Global Initiatives

3w • 

EAT Lancet report is out today (with lots of brilliant materials for a long digestion). 

A quick tip. For all of us working on #transition, Figure 17 is a gem to answer this fundamental question: 

What are the rates of change needed in the agrifood system to keep our planet safe for humans?

⬇️ Annual reductions needed in agrifood: 
-5% in emissions GHG 
-5% in red meat
-3% in irrigation water 
-2-3% in N and P overuse
-1% in land use

Ough, those are very large rates needed! With lots of transition costs associated to them. #Greenfinance need to come to the rescue there (as also pointed out in their conclusions). Climate Bonds Initiative focuses on guidance and taxonomies for how to do it! 

⬆️ Bright side: increases (i.e. growth opportunities) are essential in: 
+5% legume production
+2% vegetable production
+0.5% wages

Our technical guidance for agrifood transitions is here to help. What is your main question or doubt? Let me know! 💬

#AgrifoodCriteria #GreenFinance #AgrifoodTaxonomy

Ankur Nagpal 💰 
 • 2nd

Founder @ Carry, Silly Money, Teachable | Build durable wealth with proven tax, finance, & business tactics

4w • Edited • 

I raised $5M for my startup without a pitch deck 

Here is exactly what I did to close the round in weeks

(and be oversubscribed for two trenches of early financing)

Instead of obsessing over slides, I focused on conversations

Because the truth is early-stage investors don’t fund your deck

They fund you!

What worked for me:

- I had a clear thesis that tax optimization for founders & high earners was broken and that we could fix it

- I spoke directly to investors I knew aligned with that thesis (typically the longest time is spent just finding these people!)

 - I wrote a Notion doc that laid out the problem, solution, and why it should be built now (always critical to highlight tipping points!)

We didn’t have a 20-slide deck

Just a clear story and conviction

Ironically, our “deckless” raise was oversubscribed

And it went against all the conventional wisdom I’d been told for the last decade

If you’re a founder or aspiring entrepreneur, I’ve worked with the Notion for Startups Team (#sponsored) to put together a comprehensive system to replicate this process for your next raise

(based on my experience raising with Notion docs!) 

It includes: 

- The exact doc I used to raise the seed round for Carry (+50 more examples from the likes of Eleven Labs, Artisan AI, Series, and more)

- A list of 10,000+ angels, accelerators, and VCs you can reach out to today (can’t even imagine how long it would take to do this manually!)

- And a fundraising agent workflow built right into Notion with step-by-step instructions on how to use the prompts (no GPT or Claude required)

I didn’t have these kinds of resources when I was getting started but this genuinely would have been soooo useful (and probably save me months of my life lol)

To receive your copy, all you have to do is:

- Like this post
- Share this post
- Comment “RAISE”

---

EDIT: We've surpassed our ability to reply to all comments on a daily basis. For quick access, you can enter your enter here for the guide: https://ntn.so/silly-money

Scot Bryson 
 • 1st

Sustainable Infrastructure Architect | GP Impactful Capital | Ambassador Top Tier Impact | Space Farmer

1mo • Edited • 

Last week, I had the privilege of attending the 2025 Energy Storage Canada Conference in Toronto—a gathering of innovators, entrepreneurs, developers, and policymakers all shaping the future of energy.

I was especially honored to join The Hon. Stephen Lecce, Minister of Energy and Mines, in a discussion on how we can unlock the full potential of Ontario’s mid-sized development firms—the backbone of renewable energy in our province, and a key driver of Canada’s leadership on the global stage.

As AI adoption accelerates and energy security becomes a top priority worldwide, the role of SME project developers has never been more critical. These are the risk-takers who transform a concept into a bankable, operating solar farm, battery storage project, or long-duration energy storage asset. They lay the groundwork for billions of dollars in infrastructure that secures our grid, powers our industries, and drives sustainable growth.

Yet, too often, these firms lack the financial support they need at the earliest—and riskiest—stages of development. Institutional investors have a vital opportunity to step up: to provide risk-aligned capital that helps projects reach bankable status and ensures Canada’s track record in mining and infrastructure translates into the clean energy future.

At Impactful Capital, I am focused on championing this model here in Ontario—and scaling it across North America and globally. Canadians have an outsized role to play in advancing sustainable finance, infrastructure, and AI, and it begins with empowering the developers who build the foundation.

👉 If you’re an investor, policymaker, or industry leader passionate about accelerating sustainable infrastructure, I’d love to connect and continue the conversation.
#EnergyStorage #SustainableFinance #ImpactInvesting #CleanEnergy #OntarioLeadership #FutureOfEnergy #CanadianInnovation
